Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the presence of lice in the chicken products, as experts confirm that lice infestation is extremely rare in commercial poultry and even rarer in broilers.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove the presence of lice in the chicken products. The photographs shared on social media are not directly linked to the original post or cited from any credible sources.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the red marks on the chicken products are indicative of poultry lice infestation, without considering alternative explanations or possibilities.
Exist alternative explanation: Experts provide alternative explanations for the red marks, suggesting that they are common and harmless blood spots or meat particles that can be transferred onto chicken during processing, or slight skin color differences.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the statements from Maple Leaf Foods and Walmart, who confirm that the product depicted in the image is safe, wholesome, government inspected, and not sold in any U.S. stores.
Understate: The claim may understate the rarity of lice infestation in commercial poultry and broilers, as experts emphasize that it is extremely rare and even more so in young broiler birds.
